questions.question_text: Which IOS command creates a SIP-enabled dial peer?

discussion.content: B is correct but...lol that command alone will create an H.323 dial peer. Once the command session protocol sipv2 is added to the dial peer...it becomes a SIP dial peer. Very Cisco.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

The IOS command to create a SIP-enabled dial peer is:

php
Copy code
dial-peer voice <dial-peer number> voip
Once you enter this command, you can configure SIP-specific parameters for the dial peer using the following commands:

bash
Copy code
session protocol sipv2
destination <destination IP address/hostname>
You can then configure other parameters as needed, such as codecs, dial peer preferences, and call routing options.
Answer should be A
Answer should be A, codec mismatch generally drops the call

Selected Answer: A
Answer A (The question mentions Q0S enabled WAN Network, not LAN)
B - Call would not work - SDP would not be negotiated Cause=65 (most likely) no audio at all
C - Could actually provide those symptoms but, usually complete playback failure.
D- COS (Layer 2, think LAN) WAN cares not at L3 (DSCP-IP-Prec) (Put there to trip you up) I would need qos mapping cos to ip prec (old mls qos commands) on L3 Switch. Too much assumption here.

Then again were talking Cisco questions, not known for making sense when it comes to testing your actual abilities.

Selected Answer: D
Phone marks the packet witha wrong COS thus QoS is not working

Selected Answer: A
A is correct answer as two different location,

Selected Answer: A
A. missing Call Admission Control

Selected Answer: D
Question states that the WAN is QoS enabled.
Answers B and C will not have audio. Answer A still doesn't fix the real root cause. Answer is D, because CoS setting will properly tag audio traffic so that it is prioritized over the WAN.
A. missing Call Admission Control

Selected Answer: B
The question asks about the cause of choppy or clipped audio when a user in location X calls an extension at location Y over a QoS-enabled WAN network.
The most likely cause of this issue is: B. codec mismatch
Thus, B. codec mismatch is the most plausible cause of choppy or clipped audio in this scenario.
I think answer D. Because A is something that could help to overcome the issue but it's not a route cause of it
Maybe D ? if the phone is not set for trust then there is no QoS markings on the phone which in turn never get prioritized across the WAN. even though QoS is enabled on the WAN
Best Answer would have been if there was something related to QoS misconfigured or missing but Call Admission Control is the closest it gets to QoS. So i agree with you its (A)

questions.question_text:
A user in location X dials an extension at location Y. The call travels through a QoS-enabled WAN network, but the user experiences choppy or clipped audio.
What is the cause of this issue?

comments.content: You are correct. I attempted it in CUCM just to make sure and it denied me because of the @

discussion.content: e and d, pattern cannot accept @

Selected Answer: D
Correct Answers for This Question:
✅ D. example.com — This is the required pattern to match the domain correctly.
✅ (No valid second choice among the options given.)
Wouldn't *.* be generic and allow anything through including but not excluding any other domain???? Must route calls using example.com. E. doesn't do this

Selected Answer: DE
D and E

Selected Answer: DE
*.* is a valid pattern. Here it is in action: https://cmslab.ciscolive.com/pod1/cucm/cucmtrunk
Domain name examples are cisco.com, my-pc.cisco.com, *.com, rtp-ccm[1-5].cisco.com. Valid characters for domain names are [, -, ., 0-9, A-Z, a-z, *, and ].

questions.question_text: An engineer must route all SIP calls in the form of <user>@example.com to the SIP trunk gateway corporate local. Which two SIP route patterns can be used to accomplish this task? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
A and B are correct
Tested this in CUCM and these answers are correct.

choices.D: The Client Matter Code feature does support overlap sending because the Cisco Unified Communications Manager can determine when to prompt the user for the code.
choices.B: If you check the Allow Overlap Sending check box, the Require Client Matter Code check box becomes disabled.
choices.C: If you check the Allow Overlap Sending check box, you can also check the Require Client Matter Code check box.
choices.E: The Client Matter Code has the option to configure Authorization Level such as in the Forced Authorization Code.
choices.A: The Client Matter Code feature does not support overlap sending because the Cisco Unified CM cannot determine when to prompt the user for the code.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are correct with respect to the Client Matter Code setting in the route pattern configuration? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: https://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/voice_ip_comm/cucm/admin/3_1_2/ccmcfg/b03spchr.html#wp1029834

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

This is correct. Your brain probably tricked you and assumed C may have been the correct answer. The problem is that the ^ symbol implies that the following digit is at the start of the string. Put yourself in the shoes of the exam writers and you'll see where they're trying to trip you on questions. Failures generate revenue or the tests would be easier.

questions.question_text: A network engineer designs a new dial plan and wants to block a certain range of numbers (8135100 through 8135105). What is the most specific route pattern that can be configured to block only the numbers in this range?
